ud7.3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud7.3:1.3: Now at that time most of the people in Sāvatthī overly clung to sensual pleasures. Lustful, greedy, tied, infatuated, they lived completely addicted to sensual pleasures.
ud7.3:2.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ud7.3:2.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
ud7.3:3.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud7.3:4.1: “Clinging to sensual pleasures, to the chains of the senses,
ud7.3:4.2: blind to the faults of the fetters;
ud7.3:4.3: for sure, clinging to the fetters’ chains
ud7.3:4.4: they cannot cross the flood so vast.”
